questions.stem: A newborn infant has dysmorphic features. The pregnancy was complicated by breech presentation, decreased fetal movements, and polyhydramnios. The child demonstrates hypotonia, a flat face, flattened occiput, epicanthal folds, and abdominal distention. The most likely cause of this child's dysmorphology is:
questions.explanation: The clinical picture described, including a flat face, flattened occiput, epicanthal folds, hypotonia, and abdominal distention, are classic characteristic features of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21)[cite: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

questions.stem: A couple comes to you following the diagnosis of trisomy 21 in their 18-week fetus. They ask what medical problems may be anticipated for a child who has Down syndrome. Of the following, the medical problem that is encountered most frequently in infants who have trisomy 21 is:
questions.explanation: Among the neurological features of Down syndrome, generalized hypotonia in the first two years of life is a key characteristic[cite: 13, 14]. [cite_start]While cardiac defects are common (about 40% of cases), generalized hypotonia is a constant and prominent feature[cite: 13, 14].

questions.stem: A small for gestational age newborn is delivered at term following an uneventful pregnancy to a gravida 3, para 2, 34-year-old woman by normal spontaneous vaginal delivery. On physical examination, the newborn is noted to have a small chin, a clenched fist and hypotonia. Which of the following, the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical features of Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) include low birth weight, microcephaly with a prominent occiput, small ears, and overlapping fingers (clenched fist)[cite: 19, 20]. [cite_start]This presentation is most consistent with this diagnosis[cite: 19, 20].

questions.stem: During health supervision visit for a 5-year-old boy with hemophilia A, her mother reports that she herself is currently 16 weeks pregnant. She expresses concern about this pregnancy because her brother and two of her maternal uncles died from complications of hemophilia A. She was told at the time of her most recent ultrasonography that she is carrying a male fetus. What is the pattern of inheritance in this case?
questions.explanation: Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder[cite: 27]. [cite_start]The pattern described—affecting males and passed through the maternal line—is characteristic of an X-linked recessive condition[cite: 27, 28].

questions.stem: The parents of a child who is suffering from a metabolic disease characterized by an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern ask for your advice they intend to have a second baby. What is the risk of having affected child?
questions.explanation: In autosomal recessive inheritance, if both parents are heterozygous carriers (which they must be to have an affected child), the recurrence risk with each subsequent pregnancy is 25% for an affected child[cite: 33].

questions.stem: A mentally retarded 15-yr-old boy is found to have macroorchidism and large. prominent ears. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of Fragile X syndrome in post-pubertal males is characterized by mental retardation, macro-orchidism, large ears, and a long face with a prominent mandible[cite: 40, 41].

questions.stem: The mother of 1 year old boy complains that her child still can't sit unsupported. On examination the child has dysmorphic features and a transverse palmar crease. Local examination of the heart reveals a murmur over the left parasternal area. One of the complications of this condition is:
questions.explanation: The developmental delay and physical features (dysmorphic features, transverse palmar crease) suggest Down syndrome[cite: 43, 44]. [cite_start]A known complication of Down syndrome is a higher incidence of hypothyroidism[cite: 48, 49].

questions.stem: A 7 month male boy presented with acute onset of pallor & jaundice. Hb=3 gm/dl & reticulocytes =10%, the baby was completely healthy till he shared food with his family yesterday. What do you want to ask about?
questions.explanation: The presentation suggests acute hemolysis, possibly triggered by a dietary factor in a condition like G6PD deficiency[cite: 52, 53]. [cite_start]Since G6PD is a genetic (X-linked recessive) disorder, asking about family history in males, parental consanguinity, and affected brothers are all relevant questions[cite: 54, 55, 56, 57].

questions.stem: A 6-year-old child has growth retardation and dysmorphic features had a history of surgically repaired endocardial cushion defect. This case might be:
questions.explanation: Endocardial cushion defect is a type of cardiac anomaly commonly associated with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), affecting about 40% of cases[cite: 58, 59, 60]. [cite_start]The combination of this specific cardiac history with growth retardation and dysmorphic features makes Down syndrome the most likely diagnosis[cite: 58, 59, 60].

questions.stem: The mother of a 4 months old boy complains that her child still can't support his head. On examination the child has a flat occiput, and a transverse palmar crease. Local examination of the heart shows a hollow systolic murmur over the left parasternal area. One of the complications of this condition is:
questions.explanation: The combination of developmental delay (can't support head at 4 months), flat occiput, and a transverse palmar crease points to Down syndrome[cite: 64, 65, 66]. [cite_start]There is a higher incidence of leukemia in individuals with Down syndrome[cite: 69].

questions.stem: A 4-year-old child has brachiocephaly, intellectual delay had a history of surgically repaired duodenal atresia at birth. This case might be:
questions.explanation: Brachycephaly (flat occiput) and intellectual delay are features of Down syndrome[cite: 72, 73, 74]. [cite_start]Duodenal atresia is a well-known associated gastrointestinal anomaly found in infants with Down syndrome[cite: 72, 73, 74].

questions.stem: An infant with severe vomiting since birth. Abdominal X-ray shows double-bubble sign. Pan-systolic murmur is present over the pericardium. What is most helpful in his examination?
questions.explanation: The 'double-bubble' sign indicates duodenal atresia, and the murmur suggests a cardiac defect, both common in Down syndrome[cite: 78, 79]. [cite_start]A critical feature of Down syndrome is generalized hypotonia, so examining the infant's muscle tone would be a key part of the physical examination to support the diagnosis[cite: 81].

questions.stem: A 6 years old male infant with Down syndrome is brought by his mother because of prolonged fever. On examination he is found to have an enlarged spleen 5 cm below left costal margin. What is the most appropriate investigation to be ordered?
questions.explanation: Prolonged fever and splenomegaly in a child with Down syndrome is a red flag for a hematological malignancy, as they have a higher incidence of leukemia[cite: 86, 87, 88]. [cite_start]A complete blood picture (CBC) is the initial and most appropriate investigation to screen for leukemia[cite: 91].

questions.stem: An infant 2 days old presenting with persistent vomiting. He has dysmorphic features and severe hypotonia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The combination of dysmorphic features, severe hypotonia, and persistent early vomiting (suggesting an associated anomaly like duodenal atresia) is highly suggestive of Down syndrome[cite: 93, 94, 100].

questions.stem: A four month old female infant is brought for follow up. On examination she is found to have a systolic murmur on the left side of the chest. The skin on both sides of the neck was unusually redundant. What would you expect to find in the rest of the examination?
questions.explanation: Redundant neck skin (webbing) and a systolic murmur in a female infant are highly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45,XO)[cite: 103, 104, 105, 106]. [cite_start]A common cardiac anomaly in this syndrome is coarctation of the aorta, which would manifest as a weak or absent femoral pulse[cite: 110].

questions.stem: A routine prenatal ultrasound reveals a male fetus with meningomyelocele. You counsel her about the etiology of this defect and the risk of recurrence. The correct statement is
options: Diagnosis can be made by detection of very low levels of alpha fetoprotein in the amniotic fluid
Environmental factors will not affect the incidence of the disease.
Supplementation of maternal diet with folate decreases the incidence of this condition
This condition is transmitted as autosomal recessive
questions.explanation: Meningomyelocele is a neural tube defect with multifactorial inheritance, meaning it's influenced by both genetic and environmental factors[cite: 111, 112]. [cite_start]Maternal supplementation with folate is known to significantly decrease the incidence of neural tube defects[cite: 116].

questions.stem: A 5-year-old girl had surgery for aortic lesion. She is always short for her age.. This case might be
questions.explanation: The presentation of short stature and a history of surgery for an aortic lesion (like coarctation of the aorta) in a female is classic for Turner syndrome (45,XO)[cite: 118, 119, 123].

questions.stem: The mother of a boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy tells you that her brother was similarly affected and died in his teenage years. What is the pattern of inheritance in this case
questions.explanation: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a classic example of an X-linked recessive disorder[cite: 124, 125, 126]. [cite_start]This is supported by the family history of an affected male child and his maternal uncle[cite: 124, 125, 126].

questions.stem: A 14-year-old boy was referred because of tall stature. His height was more than the 95th percentile. He had bilateral small testes, no pubic or axillary hair. The cause of such condition is
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of a male with tall stature, small testes, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is characteristic of Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY)[cite: 132, 133, 137].

questions.stem: A female infant born to a 24-year-old woman has been diagnosed clinically as having Down syndrome. The mother is concerned about her risk of having another baby with Down syndrome. The most appropriate investigation to determine the risk of recurrence is
options: Determination of serum alpha-fetoprotein in the infant
Determination of serum alpha-fetoprotein in the mother
Karyotyping for the infant and mother
questions.explanation: In younger mothers, a translocation form of Trisomy 21 is more likely, which can be inherited from a parent who is a balanced translocation carrier[cite: 139, 140]. [cite_start]Therefore, karyotyping is needed for both the infant (to confirm the type) and the mother (to assess her carrier status), which significantly affects the recurrence risk[cite: 144].

questions.stem: A two-day- old male infant is referred to the hospital for bilious vomiting and a heart murmur. The baby was born at 37 weeks gestation to a 39 year old woman who had no prenatal care. X ray chest and abdomen were done. Which of the following is the most likely to be in the x ray?
questions.explanation: The maternal age and clinical presentation (bilious vomiting, heart murmur) are highly suggestive of Down syndrome with duodenal atresia[cite: 146, 147]. [cite_start]Duodenal atresia is characterized on an abdominal X-ray by the 'double bubble sign'[cite: 149].

questions.stem: A 17-year-old girl is 138cm tall. Her father is 175cm tall and her mother is 164cm tall. She has always been short and she had cardiac surgery at the age of 1 year. Her pubertal breast stage is Tanner B1. Which of the following is most likely to diagnose the cause of all her medical problems?
questions.explanation: The patient's short stature, history of cardiac surgery, and delayed puberty are all classic features of Turner syndrome (45, XO)[cite: 153, 154, 155]. [cite_start]A chromosomal analysis (karyotyping) is the definitive diagnostic test for this chromosomal disorder[cite: 156].

questions.stem: A disease affecting all of the daughters but none of the sons of an affected father, and 50% of the sons or daughters of an affected mother, is most likely:
questions.explanation: This pattern is characteristic of X-linked dominant inheritance. [cite_start]An affected father passes his X chromosome to all his daughters (making them affected) but not to his sons[cite: 160, 161, 164]. [cite_start]An affected mother has a 50% chance of passing the gene to any child, regardless of sex[cite: 160, 161].

questions.stem: A disease passed only through the mother and affecting both sons and daughters, with variable manifestations in the affected siblings, is most likely:
questions.explanation: Mitochondrial inheritance is exclusively transmitted by the mother to all offspring[cite: 166, 167, 168]. [cite_start]Variable manifestations (variable expressivity) can occur due to heteroplasmy[cite: 166, 167, 168].

questions.stem: Genetic diseases of numerical chromosomal abnormalities include:
questions.explanation: Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is a classic example of a numerical chromosomal abnormality[cite: 175]. [cite_start]The other options are single-gene disorders[cite: 176, 177, 178].

questions.stem: One of the following anomalies is not associated with Down syndrome:
questions.explanation: Congenital heart disease, mental retardation, and a simian crease are all common features of Down syndrome[cite: 180, 182, 183]. [cite_start]Macroorchidism (large testes) is a feature of Fragile X syndrome, not Down syndrome[cite: 181].

questions.stem: A patient with 45 XO karyotype and short stature is likely to have:
questions.explanation: A 45,XO karyotype is diagnostic for Turner syndrome, which is characterized by short stature[cite: 184, 188].

questions.stem: Autosomal recessive disorders are characterized by:
questions.explanation: A greater incidence of parental consanguinity is a key characteristic of autosomal recessive disorders, as it increases the chance that both parents carry the same recessive allele[cite: 190].

questions.stem: Characteristic feature of autosomal recessive inheritance is:
questions.explanation: In autosomal recessive inheritance, affected individuals inherit a recessive allele from both parents, who are typically phenotypically normal carriers[cite: 196].

questions.stem: X-linked recessive inheritance is characterized by:
options: All daughters of a carrier mother will be carriers
The affected father never transmits the disease to his sons
questions.explanation: In X-linked inheritance, a father transmits his Y chromosome to his sons, so he cannot pass an X-linked trait to them[cite: 202].

questions.stem: Ring chromosome is a special type of chromosomal
questions.explanation: A ring chromosome forms when there are deletions at both ends of a chromosome, and the broken ends rejoin to form a ring structure[cite: 204, 207].

questions.stem: Chromosomal structural abnormalities include:
questions.explanation: Translocation is a type of structural chromosomal abnormality where a segment of one chromosome breaks off and attaches to another chromosome[cite: 213]. [cite_start]Monosomy and Trisomy are numerical abnormalities[cite: 210, 211].

questions.stem: Chromosomal numerical abnormalities include:
questions.explanation: Trisomy, the presence of an extra chromosome, is a classic example of a numerical chromosomal abnormality[cite: 220].

questions.stem: Sex linked disorders do not include
questions.explanation: G-6-PD deficiency and hemophilia are X-linked recessive disorders, and hairy pinna is a Y-linked disorder[cite: 222, 223, 224]. [cite_start]Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease, not a sex-linked genetic disorder[cite: 225].

questions.stem: The following is not a feature in newborn term infant with Down syndrome:
questions.explanation: Brachydactyly, clinodactyly, and hypotonia are all common features of Down syndrome[cite: 227, 228, 229]. [cite_start]Webbing of the neck is a characteristic feature of Turner syndrome, not Down syndrome[cite: 230].

questions.stem: If a parent had hereditary spherocytosis, the chance to have an affected baby is:
questions.explanation: Hereditary spherocytosis is typically an autosomal dominant disorder. [cite_start]An affected heterozygous parent has a 50% chance of passing the gene to each child[cite: 234].

questions.stem: X-linked recessive disorders include:
questions.explanation: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a classic X-linked recessive disorder[cite: 239]. [cite_start]Achondroplasia is autosomal dominant, Sickle cell anemia is autosomal recessive, and Vitamin-D resistant rickets is X-linked dominant[cite: 238, 240, 241].

questions.stem: Autosomal recessive inheritance is found in:
questions.explanation: Galactosemia is a metabolic disease with an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern[cite: 244]. [cite_start]G-6-PD deficiency and Hemophilia-B are X-linked recessive, while Neurofibromatosis is autosomal dominant[cite: 243, 245, 246].
